questions.question: What does the blue line depict in the graph?
questions.explanation: A straight line on a displacement-time graph represents constant velocity (uniform motion).

questions.question: What does the part labelled P represent?
questions.explanation: The curved section P shows increasing slope, which indicates increasing velocity - this represents uniform acceleration.

questions.question: What does the part labelled Q represent?
questions.explanation: The curved section Q shows decreasing slope, which indicates decreasing velocity - this represents uniform deceleration.

questions.question: What is the average velocity?
questions.explanation: Average velocity = total displacement / total time. Since the object returns to its starting point, total displacement = 0, so average velocity = 0 m/s.

questions.question: What part represents uniform velocity?
questions.explanation: Both P and Q are curved sections, indicating changing velocity. There is no straight line section, so no part represents uniform velocity.

questions.question: What is the total displacement of the graph?
questions.explanation: For a velocity-time graph with triangular shape, displacement = area under graph = $\frac{1}{2} \times \text{base} \times \text{height}$. Symbols for the vertical height and horizontal base were not provided, so correct answer not provided.

questions.question: What does the orange line represent?
questions.explanation: A straight line on a velocity-time graph represents constant acceleration. The slope (rise/run) gives the acceleration value.

questions.question: A displacement-time graph with a vertical line represents:
questions.explanation: A vertical line on a displacement-time graph would represent infinite velocity (instantaneous change in position), which is physically impossible.

questions.question: A displacement-time graph with a horizontal line represents:
questions.explanation: A horizontal line on a displacement-time graph means position is not changing over time, so the object is at rest (zero velocity).
